review.title: On the Relation between Kappa Calculus and Probabilistic Reasoning
review.abstract: We study the connection between kappa calculus and probabilistic reasoning in diagnosis applications. Specifically, we abstract a probabilistic belief network for diagnosing faults into a kappa network and compare the ordering of faults computed using both methods. We show that, at least for the example examined, the ordering of faults coincide as long as all the causal relations in the original probabilistic network are taken into account. Our hypothesis for probabilistic reasoning has been supported by recent studies showing that an inverse relationship between kappa and probabilistic reasoning is not directly related to a causal relationship. Furthermore, the probabilistic network consists of multiple layers, so that it can be generalized to include one component, two component, and three components. To summarize, kappa is a simple and complex theory that is related to multiple layers (that is, a set of rules for the theory and the probability of a given condition, and that is, a theory of the probability of a given condition). We define the probabilistic network as a general theory for the hypothesis that the following features are required to determine whether a given condition has an equivalence to the specified condition, and that these features are necessary to determine whether a given condition has an equivalence to the specified condition. The probability of a given condition is the sum of the probability of a given condition that it has an equivalence to the specified condition, and that the following features are required to determine whether a given condition has an equivalence to the specified condition, and that they are necessary to determine whether a given condition has an equivalence to the specified condition, and that they are necessary to determine whether a given condition has an equivalence to the specified condition, and that they are necessary to determine whether a given condition has an equivalence to the specified condition. metadata.abstractText: We study the connection between kappa cal­ culus and probabilistic reasoning in diagnosis applications. Specifically, we abstract a prob­ abilistic belief network for diagnosing faults into a kappa network and compare the order­ ing of faults computed using both methods. We show that, at least for the example exam­ ined, the ordering of faults coincide as long as all the causal relations in the original prob­ abilistic network are taken into account. We also provide a formal analysis of some net­ work structures where the two methods will differ. Both kappa rankings and infinitesimal prob­ abilities have been used extensively to study default reasoning and belief revision. But lit­ tle has been done on utilizing their connec­ tion as outlined above. This is partly be­ cause the relation between kappa and prob­ ability calculi assumes that probabilities are arbitrarily close to one (or zero). The exper­ iments in this paper investigate this relation when this assumption is not satisfied. The reported results have important implications on the use of kappa rankings to enhance the knowledge engineering of uncertainty models.
